description: Summer savory (Satureja hortensis) is an annual herb native to the Mediterranean region but widely cultivated in gardens around the world. It is prized for its aromatic leaves, which have a peppery, slightly spicy flavor reminiscent of thyme and marjoram. Summer savory is commonly used as a culinary herb to flavor a variety of dishes, including soups, stews, salads, and meats. Additionally, it has a long history of use in traditional medicine for its potential digestive and antiseptic properties.
varieties: Summer savory (Satureja hortensis) is the most common variety cultivated for culinary use. There are also other varieties, such as winter savory (Satureja montana), which is more perennial and has a stronger flavor.

sowingAndPlanting.sowingIndoorsDescription: Summer savory seeds can be started indoors 6-8 weeks before the last frost date in your area. Plant seeds in pots or trays filled with well-draining potting mix. Sow seeds shallowly, barely covering them with soil, and keep the soil consistently moist. Place the pots in a warm location with indirect sunlight.
sowingAndPlanting.sowingOutdoorsDescription: Summer savory can also be directly sown outdoors after the danger of frost has passed. Choose a location with well-draining soil and full sun. Scatter seeds over the prepared soil and lightly cover them with a thin layer of soil. Keep the soil consistently moist until seeds germinate.
sowingAndPlanting.season: Summer savory can be planted outdoors after the danger of frost has passed and the soil has warmed up.

careAndMaintenance.growingDescription: Summer savory prefers well-draining soil and full sun. It is drought-tolerant once established and requires minimal maintenance. Water young plants regularly until established, then water during dry periods.
careAndMaintenance.wateringNeeds: Water newly planted summer savory regularly until established. Once established, water infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings.
careAndMaintenance.soilFertility: Summer savory is not a heavy feeder and can thrive in poor soil. However, incorporating compost or well-aged manure into the soil before planting can provide some nutrients.
careAndMaintenance.pruningRequirements: Prune summer savory plants regularly to encourage bushy growth and prevent legginess. Pinch off the growing tips to encourage branching.
careAndMaintenance.supportRequirements: Summer savory generally does not require support.

harvestingAndStorage.timeToMaturity: Summer savory can be harvested for culinary use once the plants are well-established, usually within 60-80 days after planting.
harvestingAndStorage.storageRecommendations: Harvest summer savory leaves as needed for culinary use. Use fresh leaves immediately for the best flavor. Alternatively, you can dry summer savory leaves by hanging them upside down in a warm, well-ventilated area until they are completely dry. Store dried summer savory leaves in an airtight container in a cool, dark place.
harvestingAndStorage.harvestDescription: Harvest summer savory leaves by snipping them from the plant as needed. Harvest leaves when they are young and tender for the best flavor.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Beans
goodCompanionPlants.description: Summer savory is a beneficial companion for beans as it can help repel pests like bean beetles and improve their growth and flavor. Planting summer savory near beans can attract beneficial insects like bees and parasitic wasps, which can help pollinate the flowers and control pests. Additionally, the aromatic foliage of summer savory can enhance the overall flavor of beans when grown together.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Onions
goodCompanionPlants.description: Summer savory is a good companion for onions as it can help deter pests like onion flies and improve their growth and flavor. Planting summer savory near onions can create a fragrant and visually appealing garden while providing natural pest control. Additionally, the aromatic foliage of summer savory can complement the taste of onions when used together in culinary dishes.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Tomatoes
goodCompanionPlants.description: Summer savory is a beneficial companion for tomatoes as it can help repel pests like aphids, spider mites, and tomato hornworms. Planting summer savory near tomatoes can attract beneficial insects like predatory beetles and parasitic wasps, which can help control pests and reduce the need for chemical pesticides. Additionally, the aromatic foliage of summer savory can enhance the flavor of tomatoes when grown together.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Lettuce
goodCompanionPlants.description: Summer savory is a good companion for lettuce as it can help repel pests like aphids, slugs, and snails. Planting summer savory near lettuce can create a protective barrier against insect damage while providing additional flavor and aroma to the garden. Additionally, the aromatic foliage of summer savory can complement the taste of lettuce when used together in salads and other dishes.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Cabbage
goodCompanionPlants.description: Summer savory is a beneficial companion for cabbage as it can help deter pests like cabbage moths and cabbage worms. Planting summer savory near cabbage can create a fragrant and visually appealing garden while providing natural pest control. Additionally, the aromatic foliage of summer savory can enhance the overall flavor of cabbage when grown together.

badCompanionPlants.name: Fennel
badCompanionPlants.description: Fennel should be avoided as a companion for summer savory as it may inhibit the growth of nearby plants, including summer savory. Additionally, fennel may attract pests like aphids and caterpillars, which can also damage summer savory plants. Planting fennel near summer savory may lead to competition for resources and reduced overall health for both plants.

badCompanionPlants.name: Beans
badCompanionPlants.description: While summer savory is beneficial for beans, planting beans near summer savory may not be ideal as it can lead to competition for resources like water and nutrients. Both plants have similar soil and watering requirements, which may result in reduced growth and vigor if grown together. Additionally, beans and summer savory may attract the same pests, leading to increased pest pressure on both plants.

badCompanionPlants.name: Peas
badCompanionPlants.description: Peas should be avoided as companions for summer savory as they may compete for resources like water, nutrients, and space. Planting peas near summer savory can lead to reduced growth and vigor for both plants due to competition. Additionally, peas and summer savory may attract similar pests, increasing the risk of pest infestations in the garden.

tipsAndTricks: Choose a planting location with well-drained soil and full sun exposure for summer savory.
Plant summer savory seeds directly in the garden or start them indoors and transplant after the last frost.
Water summer savory plants regularly, keeping the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged.
Mulch around summer savory plants to retain moisture and suppress weeds.
Fertilize summer savory plants with a balanced fertilizer every 4-6 weeks during the growing season.
Harvest summer savory leaves as needed for culinary use by cutting them from the plant. Harvest before the plant flowers for the best flavor.
Monitor plants regularly for signs of pests such as aphids and spider mites. Handpick pests or use insecticidal soap as needed.
Watch for symptoms of diseases like powdery mildew and botrytis blight. Provide good air circulation and avoid overhead watering to reduce humidity around plants.
Summer savory can be harvested throughout the growing season. Cut back plants by one-third to encourage bushy growth and prolong the harvest.
Use fresh or dried summer savory leaves to flavor a variety of dishes, including meats, poultry, soups, stews, and bean dishes.
